comments.commentBody:
Hope none of you NYT editors and rewrite people have suffered permanent injury from the above attempts to pat yourselves on the back. No matter what the stated goals and procedures for ensuring some sort of "objectivity," I am content with openly expressed opinions and, even, openly expressed biases.

Today's article on the design and marketing philosophies of Apple by Steve Lohr (who he?) affords a good example, to me, of falling way short of open acknowledgement. In some sort of attempt to broach, if not bash, perceived stylistic and philosophical shortcomings of the Apple-Jobs juggernaut, Lohr quotes gurus John Kao and Paul Saffo. At no time does a useful kind of fair disclosure come into play.

just what kind of (Microsoft?) clunkers do these alleged experts use anyhow? Why do satisfied users of Apple products, like me, pay the extra bucks for the laptops and other products that work so well, especially compared to the MS.-megalopoly crap?

Come on, NYT writers, let your biases hang out in the sunlight; and don't fear the quality and legitimacy of marketplace choices that millions of us make.

From the Bluegrass to the Alps to Oz...Thanks Rog for another GS...we can't get enough!

Gary Thomas
Kentucky
USA

The Pro Bowl was on today? What? I was busy learning to knit, washing the floor, counting to 492 by 3, and seeing how much mayonnaise it takes to make a life-size sculpture of Vincent D'onofrio's head. I am so upset I missed it. I mean, how exciting is a NFL game without blitzing, vanilla defenses, and no big hits? AWESOME!
What, no Rex Grossman?
Is Rex Ryan a WWE manager?

Now we've got Freeney on one side and Shockey on the other hobbled going into the game. But what strikes me is this. I can't recall a Super Bowl in which a key player was knocked out of action during the game itself -- especially early, a la Colt McCoy in the FBS title game (or some years before, QB Major Harris of West Virginia, vs Notre Dame in that year's "unofficial" title game).

Can anyone recall such a Super Bowl incident? Is the SB charmed? And who do you like better as a backup quarterback: Curtis Painter or Mark Brunell?

Corrections and retractions (It must have been hoof in mouth disease):

It appears that one of my previous posts might have been disqualified, I suspect, because it contained an inopportune use of the word "zombie." I now realize that this was merely a malapropism and that, in fact, I had likely intended to use one of the more politically correct terms, "undead" or "living dead." Neither of these, however, was intended either to reference or insult co-workers, who can be seen to be fully animated... as soon as they leave work and hit the bars [and might truly be considered "office zombies" only until 5:00 p.m., Fridays]. Nor was either of these terms intended as an affront to management, although such might be viewed as living off blood, sweat, and human flesh as surely as any fictional "vampire" or "zombie" (especially when repeating how much they need our "brains, brains, brains, brains, brains, brains, brains...").

Finally, in yet another post, having been under the impression that swaddling cloths (bandages) would have been readily available in any stable because they could be used to wrap the lower legs of horses -- Do horses have calves? -- for racing, jumping, or other taxing equestrian events, I might have made too much of the questionably quoted or translated "swaddling clothes." Until the mid-1700s, one source suggests, newborn infants in the Orient were, in fact, "swaddled" in strips of cloth, which bindings severely limited range of movement and often resulted in nasty cases of what is now commonly known as "diaper rash." All wound up in strips of cloth like that, and in a whole rash of hurt, one can only imagine how any baby might have cried for its mummy. (In rare cases, it seems, the practice was continued until, as the child matured, post-natal crying eventually gave way to an elemental form of singing, which not a few ethnomusicologists currently lean toward classifying as an early example of "wrap music.")
When I was a child, my grandmother would help me fall asleep at night by singing me a soft, sweet melody, which she referred to as the "Bronze Lullaby"
My grandmother mixed up the words cocktailsl and highballs - I'll leave the rest to the readers

a friend viewing a picture of moorish architecture remarked how much she loved the minuets on the roof..

another time she remarked that she couldn't focus because she was in the mist of things
Have you read Harper Lee's "Tequila Mockingbird"?
Tacticating (tactical) aircraft?
Noting bird-watchers at the side of the highway, she remarked, "That must be the autobahn society."

Malapropisms

(1) The former president based his strategy on schlock and gall.

(2) The nation waited eagerly for the president to address the fate of the onion.

(3) Congress is too pre-occupied with pig business hobbies and courtesan politics to help the American people.

(4) She's creating the great American hovel.

(5) Smog is caused by bourbon solution in the atmosphere.
On a TV report of a demonstration at an L.A. high school, a female student looked at the gaggle of photographers and yelled, "Look at all the Pavarotti!"

This is indeed a great blog! Thanks for pointing it out, Qw, and I thought I recognized that malaprop essay (#47). :) Perhaps I will have to take a look at this one on a weekly basis in addition to TierneyLab...

As far as malaprops, one of my favorite historical ones is when people talk about the monks who practiced "flatulation" on themselves for punishment (flagellation).

I also once heard a little boy, when asked what he wanted to be when he grew up, say "I wanna be a obstruction man" (construction).

Here is an example of what Qw was alluding to in #47 (from our word puzzle work on TierneyLab), although these are made up rather than having been heard:

Not extractly sure if malapropisms work well for names, and some give more immaterial to work with than others, but this astounded like fun anyways ( sloe around the office this mourning ). No offensive intended in the content and I apologist in advance for any omitted names in this list of car-men players in this blog...

BTW, if anyone is interested, the comments from the malaproprisms week at the TierneyLab blog can be found at
http://tierneylab.blogs.nytimes.com...

Some more made-up ones from the TierneyLab malaprops puzzle:

Today’s puzzle is especially intestine in that the individual problems do indeed constipate “light snacks.” Especially for those of us who are counting celeries . In the first plumbum , we have to use edition, obstruction, mystification, and derision to work those numbers. Mission implausible? I think not, for 1 / 9 + 1 * 9 surely equals 10. In the second, we are propelled to play with our McNuggets to find the secrete and largesse indicated quantity, which happens to be 43. In the third, we are suppressed to use common cents to provide change for a dollop . This, as I have vindicated , is 4 panties, 1 knuckle, 2 dames, and 3 courters . In question #4, the math genuses get to finger out optimal damnations for all of the coins, with a few variations. I came up with 2 1s, 2 3s, 2 9s, and 3 27s, although I am ascertain there is a better absolution . Of course, the malpractices are next, as contained in this Pendergraft . And vinylly , Pradeep has requested that we smirch our couch epistolary for loose change and other Messianic items, in hopes of adding them all to his junk correction .
Somebody must be expecting some great prizes because we're giving "a hundred and ten percent!"

Heard in an earthquake-prone area of northern California: "Dude, this place was like Epi Central!"

And after the steeple was toppled from a church in Watsonville (same quake): "Dude! That was hit with, like, an axe of God!"

A woman I worked with had several that almost made sense.
A neighbor of hers had a dog & she didn't know the breed, but it howled at night. She thought it was a bugle hound.
She was very fond of fruit compost.
I hope the Yankees get to play in the World Serious!
Abstinence makes the heart grow fonder.

Man 1: You have to admit you were a bit tepid with that proposal.
Woman 1: Are you calling me dumb?
Woman 2: Stop it, Man 1, don't you dare call her mellifluous.

Desmond Tutu, Nobel Laureate, to a rally of people protesting the War on Iraq: "I'm clapping you!"

On the shoulder? In leg irons? Okay, on the shoulder, figuratively (as he literally applauded the protesters for their efforts on behalf of world peace).
